text: option box spreads I'm going to walk you through what they are how I use them why they might be useful for your toolkit because for me specifically these are actually an important part of what I do and namely because a lot of the strategies that I use like the coverage triangle the diagonal the unlocked leverage and one of the ways you can capitalize on The Leverage is putting the money to use that is otherwise scheduled for those other strategies as I listed them so I'm going to walk you through the strategy first and then give you a couple examples on how I like to use them and then finally the management of the strategy so what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to all the hours let's get right to it so the very first thing what is an option box spread well realistically the reason why we use this is It's a way to Arbitrage the risk-free rate from the market and if you don't know what Arbitrage means it's essentially a way for us to guarantee a profit with no risk and there are instances that you can do it but no notice how I say via the risk-free rate the reason why that part is important is because there's not this magical trade that you're finding that just gives you free money this is just a essential way to either loan money to the market or get money from the market yep

text: not there that's a problem so one of the things I tell people is like let's say for example I have a really deep in the money short put I'm not going to put the capital for that trade into a box spread because the propensity for early assignment is still relatively High especially if there's not a lot of time value left in those options so that's one scenario that I would not deploy a box spread the second scenario that you have to consider is the timing of your trades so for example in this box spread I have 11 days left to go that means that the cash is going to come available in 11 days I don't want to buy this back early because that's more fees and that's another spread that you have to cross all eats into the profitability I want to take this trade to expiration and let it expire it's a cash settled product so even if one of these is in the money and one of them is not in the money or whatever it doesn't matter that's another reason why I trade the SPX is because it's cash settled it doesn't matter if it winds up in between the legs it's going to be a full profit if I let it expire but let's say for example I had a trade in iwm that's going to require X number of dollars and that actually expires on the 9th of March

text: has time left in the trade now I want to talk to you about one other risk in this trade and that is the risk-free rate so as the risk-free rate changes when you put the trade on obviously you're establishing your value but let's say rates increased while I was in this trade well then now I'm kind of not in an ideal scenario because there's a better rate available and I'm locked into this rate so it's one of the reasons why I prefer shorter term time frames especially in a dynamic interest rate environment so box spreads are a fantastic way to utilize leverage and the rest of the cash in the portfolio why it's being used for other things you just have to be pragmatic and smart about the way you do it but this has been one of the Hallmarks of what I tend to do especially coupled with the covered strangle strategy because the coverage triangle is very Capital intensive so this is a way to earn something while the coverage strangle is still working and still has all the cash available to it so while rates start to increase or they maintain a level that at least makes sense to run this strategy I tend to run it now when we were in essentially a near zero interest rate environment I didn't bother with it because after fees there wasn't much to walk out with but that's not always the case especially as
